subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: how to transcribe air and ear
msgSnippet: ... That is a very weak argument and also avoids the topic. I am trying to get clarity on the use of these vowels amongst others. Saying that originally there
messageBody:
John Cowan wrote:
>
>
> paulhtremblay scripsit:
>
> > > There can be no material doubt that they referred originally to the
> > > IPA's [A], [O], and [Q] (in the SAMPA transcription of IPA into ASCII),
> >
> > Of course there can be tons of doubt because not everyone speaks
> > British English.
>
> Please note the word "originally". QS was originally designed around
> RP, and RP uses these three sounds in those three words.

That is a very weak argument and also avoids the topic. I am trying to
get clarity on the use of these vowels amongst others. Saying that
originally there was no doubt (when for almost everyone here there is
great doubt) does nothing to further the debate.

>
> > How can you possibly say there is no doubt when other users have
> > expressed confusion and when you know that no everyone speaks British
> > English?
>
> There is no doubt about the above historical and phonological facts.

Which most of us are not aware of. So again, there is great doubt.


>
> I don't.


So I'm not supposed to be able to follow your posts when you make
contradictions! By the way, could you please tell me how much you use
QS? I asked you that in another post and I guess you never got around to
answering it.

Paul
